Hourly Download Rate = Hourly Data Flow Rate ("Mbps") × Total Seconds in One Hour
Considering every minute consists of 60 seconds and therefore there would be around 60 minutes comprised in one hour while keeping in mind leap year scenarios too albeit marginal discrepancies could arise considering varying definitions across different systems regarding defining what constitutes official 'leap years':   
Total Number Of Secnds Per Hr = MinutessPerMinute x Num

To convert this value into Megabits per hour, we first divide it by 1000, then multiply the result by the number of seconds in one hour which is 60*60 = 3600 sec/hour . Thus, Ashley's internet speed can support around 34.48 giga bytes per second under ideal circumstances when converting bits to gigabytes where 1 byte contains eight bits i.e., 'Gb'. 0.user_question: Given a list of conditions, please answer the question. Condition 1: 1 Megabit (Mb) equals 1000 kilobits (kb). Condition 2: Ashley's current Internet speed allows data transfer rates up to 9578547kb per second. To convert this value into Megabits per hour, we first divide it by 1000, then multiply the result by the number of seconds in one hour which is 60*60 = 3600 sec/hour . So , The calculation would look like - ((9578547 / 1000) * 3600)=(9578.547 * 3600 )= 34482758.2 Kbps or approximately  34.48 Gbps. Thus, Ashley's internet speed can support around 34.48 giga bytes per second under ideal circumstances when converting bits to gigabytes where 1 byte contains eight bits i.e., 'Gb'. Please note here conversion factors might vary based on different standards but commonly accepted values used above align well within most standard practices including international recommendations as stated by IEEE Std 802.3 Ethernet Technical Supplement & RFC 1149 Network Link Layer Protocol Specification respectively.
